questions.question: At first Alex did his training in the (1) __________ department.
He did not have a qualification from school in (2) __________.
He thinks he should have done the diploma in (3) __________ skills.
The youngest trainee was (4) __________ years old.
Trainees receive the same amount of (5) __________ as permanent staff.
Trainees go to (6) __________ one day per month.
The company is in a convenient (7) __________.
Applicants are advised not to wear (8) __________.
Applicants are advised not to be (9) __________.
Applicants should make sure they (10) __________.
Annie recommends that when cross-country skiing, the visitors should
options: get away from the regular trails.
stop to enjoy views of the scenery.
go at a slow speed at the beginning.

questions.question: What does Annie tell the group about this afternoon's dog-sled trip?
options: Those who want to can take part in a race.
Anyone has the chance to drive a team of dogs.
One group member will be chosen to lead the trail.

questions.question: What does Annie say about the team relay event?
options: All participants receive a medal.
The course is 4 km long.
Each team is led by a teacher.

questions.question: On the snow-shoe trip, the visitors will
options: visit an old gold mine.
learn about unusual flowers.
climb to the top of a mountain.

questions.question: The cost of accommodation in the mountain hut includes
options: a supply of drinking water.
transport of visitors' luggage.
cooked meals.

questions.question: If there is a storm while the visitors are in the hut, they should
options: contact the bus driver.
wait until the weather improves.
use the emergency locator beacon.

questions.question: Highland trail
options: it has a good place to stop and rest
it is suitable for all abilities
it involves crossing a river
it demands a lot of skill
it may be closed in bad weather
it has some very narrow sections

questions.question: Pine trail
options: it has a good place to stop and rest
it is suitable for all abilities
it involves crossing a river
it demands a lot of skill
it may be closed in bad weather
it has some very narrow sections

questions.question: Stony trail
options: it has a good place to stop and rest
it is suitable for all abilities
it involves crossing a river
it demands a lot of skill
it may be closed in bad weather
it has some very narrow sections

questions.question: Loser's trail
options: it has a good place to stop and rest
it is suitable for all abilities
it involves crossing a river
it demands a lot of skill
it may be closed in bad weather
it has some very narrow sections

questions.question: What was Jack's attitude to nutritional food labels before this project?
options: He didn't read everything on them.
He didn't think they were important.
He thought they were too complicated.

questions.question: Alice says that before doing this project she
options: was unaware of what certain foods contained.
was too lazy to read food labels.
was only interested in the number of calories.

questions.question: When discussing supermarket brands of pizza, Jack agrees with Alice that
options: the list of ingredients is shocking.
he will hesitate before buying pizza again.
the nutritional label is misleading.

questions.question: Jack prefers the daily value system to other labelling systems because it is
options: more accessible.
more logical.
more comprehensive.

questions.question: What surprised both students about one flavour of crisps?
options: The percentage of artificial additives given was incorrect.
The products did not contain any meat.
The labels did not list all the ingredients.

questions.question: What do the students think about research into the impact of nutritional food labelling?
options: It did not produce clear results.
It focused on the wrong people.
It made unrealistic recommendations.

questions.question: Which TWO things surprised the students about the traffic-light system for nutritional labels? (Choose TWO)
options: its widespread use
the fact that it is voluntary for supermarkets
how little research was done before its introduction
its unpopularity with food manufacturers
the way that certain colours are used

questions.question: Which TWO things surprised the students about the traffic-light system for nutritional labels? (Choose TWO)
options: its widespread use
the fact that it is voluntary for supermarkets
how little research was done before its introduction
its unpopularity with food manufacturers
the way that certain colours are used

questions.question: Which TWO things are true about the participants in the study on the traffic-light system? (Choose TWO)
options: They had low literacy levels.
They were regular consumers of packaged food.
They were selected randomly.
They were from all socio-economic groups.
They were interviewed face-to-face.

questions.question: Which TWO things are true about the participants in the study on the traffic-light system? (Choose TWO)
options: They had low literacy levels.
They were regular consumers of packaged food.
They were selected randomly.
They were from all socio-economic groups.
They were interviewed face-to-face.

questions.question: 1623: In Constantinople, the ruler ordered the (31) __________ of every coffee house.
Coffee shops were compared to (32) __________.
They played an important part in social and (33) __________ changes.
Types of coffee were often named according to the (34) __________ they came from.
In Brazil and the Caribbean, most cultivation depended on (35) __________.
In Java, coffee was used as a form of (36) __________.
Coffee became almost as important as (37) __________.
The move towards the consumption of (38) __________ in Britain did not also take place in the USA.
Prices dropped because of improvements in (39) __________.
Industrial workers found coffee helped them to work at (40) __________.
